bibl.title: [Letter] 1840 Oct. 17, Jackson, Tennessee [to] Mary Jane Chester, Columbia, Ten[nessee] / John Chester
bibl.author: Chester, John
bibl.note: This document is a letter written to Mary Jane Chester on October 17, 1840, and contains two letters. The first letter is from her brother John, and discusses family events, mainly one involving a dinner where Andrew Jackson, Governor Polk, and Judge Grundy were in attendance. The second letter is from her mother, Elizabeth, and expresses feelings of love for her daughter.

projectDesc.p: Created for the University of Tennessee Digital Library

editorialDecl.p: Quotation marks retained as data except inside q tags
Errors in transcription of the printed text controlled with X-Metal 2.1 spell-checker; text has also been thoroughly proofread.
Corrections and normalization represented by editorial tags.
Catchwords and directional notes such as "turn page over" have been omitted.

refsDecl.p: ID attributes provided for only those pages, chapters, or illustrations toward which a reference or figure points.

opener.add:
post mark seal John Chester
Answered Paid 18 ¾

address.addrLine: Care of Saml. P. Walker Esq.

opener.add:
My Dear Mother
and Sister
17 Octr 1840

div1.p: Papa Recieved your kind and affectionat letter on yesterday and it gave us great Pleasure to here that you have entirely recovered from your sickness and had commenced school. He also recieved a letter from Mr Smith spekeing in very ⁁ flattering terms of your Progress. Aunt Narsissa has been very sick again but she is better now and She has give out the notion of coming up untill Christmas Cousin Jane is very sick. Cousin Martha Hine has a fine boy named William Edward.
We had a great dinner here on the 8.
Uncle Jackson, Govener Polk, Judge Grundy, and a great many others distinguished strangers were here.
The Procession was formed in front of the court House dooer, and they marched up to uncle Wills When Uncle Jackson was recived and conducted under a large escort to the spring.

He was recieved in the stand by Mr McClanahan and welcomed in a very handsom speech to which Uncle Jackson replied, You will see th Procedings in
th union. Papa says that you must ask cousin Sam for the union and Read it yourself.

We had great feastings you may depend; Their was 65 Beeves 70 or 80 Muttons and 160 shoates all barbacude very nice and they had an ash poon baked in one of the Barbacue pits 4 feet Long 9 foot wide it had 2 ½ Bushels of Meal in it and the name of Jackson Written on it the Poon was Placed at th head of one of the Tables and on it was Placed 1 Turkey 9 Pigs & uncle Jackson, Governer Polk, Judge Grundy, dined on it. Their were 6 tables in all ¾ of a Mile long. Miss Catherin Fuftin was married to Dr. Jones last Thursday night. I remember of no other news that would interest you.
We had a great Deal of Rain by which it is feared that it will injure th crops.
Mama, Papa, and all of the children, Aunt N Aunt P & uncle Will sends their love to you and all of the servants desin to be Remembered to
I Greet you with Love and affection and feel thankful to the giver of all good for your recovery, I shall write you next week
